description: From 1599 or earlier (1530 in a Scottish document), apparently from Shakespeare with this spelling. Perhaps from Middle English mewen (“to whimper”)  +‎ -le (frequentative suffix).

entries.meaning: A soft cry or whimper; an act of mewling.
examples: There would have been total silence if it hadn't been for the sea nearby, mewling. Indeed, that same mewl added to the sleepy image that filled the dormant house.

verbs.description: mewl (third-person singular simple present mewls, present participle mewling, simple past and past participle mewled)

entries.meaning: To cry weakly with a soft, high-pitched sound; to whimper; to whine.
examples: My father started rubbing and rubbing on Mittens, scruffying her fur the wrong way, and she mewled her protests.
